note: Barton’s diverse publications span prehistoric technology, land use and ecology, geoarchaeology, Darwinian theory, prehistoric rock art, and the peopling of the Americas.
title: Michael Barton is professor of anthropology in the School of Human Evolution and Social Change and director of the Center for Social Dynamics and Complexity at Arizona State University, visiting research professor at the Universitat de Valencia (Spain), and visiting scientist at the National Center for Atmospheric Research. A Fulbright Senior Fellow, he holds a PhD in archaeology and geosciences from the University of Arizona. Barton’s research interests center on human ecology and the dynamics of Quaternary landscapes. He has directed interdisciplinary research in the American Southwest and the Mediterranean on the longterm socioecology of prehistoric hunter-gatherers and the beginnings of agriculture
Manuel Calvo Trías is lecturer in archaeology in the Department of Historic Sciences and Art Theory at the University of Balearics Islands

Ana Delgado is associate professor of prehistory at the Universitat Pompeu Fabra (Barcelona). Her research interests include social and gender archaeology, cultural contact, and colonial and postcolonial studies. She has focused on the archaeology of the diasporas and colonies in the ancient Mediterranean and in the analysis of the contact and conflict relations between immigrant groups and native communities, treating this subject from a intersectionality perspective. She is the co-editor of De Tartessos a Manila: siete estudios coloniales y poscoloniales

Mercedes Murillo-Barroso obtained her MSc in technology and analysis of archaeological materials at University College London through a Marie Curie Early Stage Training (EST) fellowship. She is currently a PhD candidate at the Spanish High Council for Scientific Research, Madrid, supported by a scholarship from the Spanish government’s Formación de Personal Investigador (FPI) program. Her ongoing research focuses on production and consumption processes of silver in the Argaric society (second millennium cal B.C.) and the first Phoenician settlements in southern Iberia (first millennium cal B.C.), integrating archaeometallurgical analyses with social issues such as the relationship between the organization of silver production and consumption and the evolution of social complexity

title: Antonio Ramos Millán is professor of prehistory in the Department of Prehistory and Archaeology in the University of Granada (Spain), where he teaches archaeological theory and Late Prehistory

note: He also participates in several projects related to rock art developed in Sweden, Chile, and Colombia. He has published a number of articles in international journals, such as Trabajos de Prehistoria, World Archaeology, Journal of Indo-European Studies, and Journal of Archaeological Science.
title: Manuel Santos Estévez obtained his PhD in history in 2004 at the University of Santiago de Compostela (USC). His main research is oriented to rock art, sculpture, and landscape archaeology. Since 1995 he has been a researcher in the Landscape Archaeology Laboratory at USC and of the Institute of Galician Studies Padre Sarmiento (CSIC) and, since 2009, a hired researcher at the Institute of History (CCHS-CSIC). He has directed fifty archaeological projects, among which is the Campo Lameiro archaeological work
Inés Sastre holds a PhD in geography and history from the Universidad Complutense

She is a scientific researcher in the research group “Social Structure and Territory: Landscape Archaeology” (Institute of History [IH], Center for Humanities and Social Sciences [CCHS], High Council for Scientific Research [CSIC]). Her research is centered on the analysis of the forms of social dependence in ancient societies and their processes of change, especially in the pre-Roman and Roman rural territories of the Northwestern Iberian Peninsula. A fundamental axis in her work has been the elaboration of research methods based on the combined analysis of the archaeological record and written sources (epigraphy and literary sources) and the development of a theoretical basis on different society models, their forms of inequality, and their territorial organization
